repnme.cdata!:
Djibouti - HIV/AIDS, Malaria, and
            Tuberculosis Control Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the HIV/AIDS, Malaria, and
            Tuberculosis Control Project for Djibouti were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was low, Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was highly satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: getting the support at the highest political level
            made a huge difference in implementation. The creation of
            the Interministerial Committee, later transformed into the
            CCMI (Comite de Coordination Multisectorielle et
            Inter-partenariale), succeeded in mobilizing the
            multi-sectoral and community-based activities and donor
            support. Moreover, it was important to engage religious
            leaders. Trained religious leaders and imams were often
            called on to conduct advocacy and question and answer
            sessions. The early delays in implementation were caused by
            the focus on strengthening the management capacity and
            qualified staffing of the newly established Executive
            Secretariat (ES) and on the development of detailed
            guidelines and procedures. However, later on, this
            investment accelerated the implementation guided by the
            protocols and procedures manuals. Although prevention of
            HIV/AIDS, including Voluntary Counseling and Testing (VCT),
            remains the most cost-effective weapon in the fight against
            the epidemic compared to Antiretroviral (ARV) treatment,
            insight and closer consideration of epidemiologic and
            cultural aspects led to the conclusion that prevention
            (particularly VCT services) would fail unless ARV treatment
            was simultaneously offered. As a result, the project
            introduced and scaled up ARV treatment until the GF (Global
            Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria) took over. It
            was later shown in service statistics that VCT utilization
            increased, particularly among the young and educated, when
            they were assured of access to affordable treatment.

repnme.cdata!:
Djibouti - HIV/AIDS, Malaria and
            Tuberculosis Control Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The HIV/AID and Tuberculosis Control
            Project for Djibout will assist the Government in setting up
            and implementing a response against HIV/AIDS, sexually
            transmitted infections (STIs), malaria, and tuberculosis
            (TB), of which the latter two are important risk cofactors.
            There are 4 components to the project: 1) The capacity
            building and policy development will aim at strengthening
            Djibouti's capacity to cope with the spread of
            HIV/AIDS, and to control malaria and tuberculosis. 2) The
            Ministry of Health (MOH) and more broadly the health
            community have special responsibilities for the prevention
            and management of HIV/AIDS/STIs, malaria, and other
            opportunistic infections - including malaria, and
            tuberculosis. 3) As demonstrated in other countries, in
            order for the control of HIV/AIDS to be effective, it is
            necessary to have a multisectoral approach to better target
            priority vulnerable groups. The preparation process of the
            National Strategic Plan has demonstrated that the MOH could
            not by itself deliver all the essential prevention, and
            impact. 4) In order to enlist communities in controlling
            HIV/AIDS, malaria, and tuberculosis, and to provide them
            with the means to mitigate the impact of these diseases, it
            is necessary to provide resources at the local level.

Djibouti - HIV/AIDS, Malaria and
